title: 110_hr2713
content: The Act titled the "Joseph H. Seall Act of 2007" waives the 5-month waiting period for disability benefits for terminally ill beneficiaries. The "Joseph H. Seall Act of 2007" allows the Commissioner of Social Security to waive the waiting period for disability insurance benefits for terminally ill individuals, based on specified criteria. The Commissioner of Social Security may waive the waiting period for widow's insurance benefits based on disability if the individual is terminally ill and the waiting period would cause undue hardship. The Commissioner of Social Security can waive the waiting period for widower's insurance benefits if the individual is terminally ill and the waiting period would cause undue hardship. The Commissioner of Social Security may waive the waiting period for widower's insurance benefits if the individual is terminally ill with a life expectancy of 6 months or less. The Commissioner of Social Security may waive the five-month waiting period for disability benefits if the individual is terminally ill with a life expectancy of 6 months or less. The effective dates for these amendments apply to specific sections of the Social Security Act. The amendments made by this Act apply to disability benefits under specific sections of the Social Security Act, with different effective dates for different provisions. SEC. 3. STUDY REGARDING DISABILITY CLAIMS PROCESSING. The Commissioner of Social Security will conduct a study on processing disability insurance claims, including methods used by State agencies and the Social Security Administration, comparing them to other agencies and providers in the private sector. The Commissioner of Social Security will report recommendations to Congress on improving methods and procedures for processing disability benefit claims, including legislative changes to expedite the determination process and address the backlog.
